title: Here is some info about the power creep and gold efficiency of post-nerf Ardent Censer!

embed.description: Magic › Cooldown Reduction Movement › Other Movement Items Ardent Censer is a legendary item in League of Legends.[1] Windspeaker's Blessing.Ardent Censer's bonus healing and shielding passive stacks additively with , , , and [2] It stacks multiplicatively with Spirit Visage , giving a 43% total increase when directly healing anyone holding that item.

body:
Ardent censer, released in patch 4.10 and for 2200 gold it gave 30 ability power, 10 flat mana regen (per 5 seconds), 10% cooldown reduction, unique passive of 8 percent movespeed, and unique passive "your shields and heals on another unit grant them 25 percent attack speed for 6 seconds."

Today for an **increase of only 100 gold** (total of 2300) you gain 30 ability power, 15% heal and shield power, and the unique passive giving yourself and the ally you are shielding and healing 20-35 percent attack speed and 20-35 on-hit magic damage, along with the exact same build path. 

Ardent censer is **108.34 percent gold efficient** without its passives. If it is applied to **one ally** and yourself it is **195.3 - 260.51 percent gold efficient**(based on level, and with all passives). If this passive is applied to **all allies** including yourself it is **325.73 - 488.78 percent gold efficient** (based on level, and with all passives).  

A whopping 488 percent gold efficient if you press r on janna or soraka, seems pretty fair right. For comparison sunfire cape's gold efficiency is only 80.46 percent without the passive. Most tank items that give armor without their passives are only at around 75 - 80 percent gold efficiency. Magic resistance tank items are around 90% gold efficiency without their passives.

Just goes to show how stupid this item actually is (sorry for all the numbers).

In mid-season, one of our projects was to increase the attractiveness and general agency of the support role. By giving supports access to income streams that they never had before, they are also much more impactful. 

For reference, Redemption and Locket also are very cost efficient , though most of their power is in the actives. I would say what players find particularly offensive (though correct me if I'm wrong) is the relatively low skill expression of Ardent's power. So yes, I would agree that the role and items have been power crept, but this needs to be held in the context of supports having less gold income as well.

I don't think giving them busted items that define their role more than the actual champs is a good call to make them more attractive.
I for one liked supporting every now and then in previous seasons, but i totally hate it these days because i'm a slave of the meta items and getting those items seems to be the main purpose of supports.
Before, supports had powerfull kits to compensate for the low income, **and they could controll vision all by them selfs**, but with the puny wardstones, warding limit and so on, a single support by far is not enough to controll vision anymore, so for me, supports lost alot strategic power and you now try to compensate that by (over) buffing their fighting impact, which contributes directly to the overall powercreep.
Even worse, you boost their combat power with absurd item effects rather than giveing them more potent income or buffing their kits.
I also don't see how supports got acces to income streams that they didn't have before, atleaset within the last ~4 seasons...
Thank you, a champion shouldn't be defined by the item's they get but by the kit's they have.

So you suggest every support gets a buff?
I play support when duoing -never solo- and I finally feel like I have a high impact. The items are very strong good and cost effective, and I love them for that. 
Those items kind of define supports right now, true, but I prefer that over being reduced to a wardbot with either engage, poke or peel. That's what it was like for the longest time.

I'm not sure where you've been, but the entire group stage first week was actually dictated by Ardent Censer Enchanter. The thing that it shows is that enchanters rarely dictated the meta beforehand, as Janna or Lulu were more situational picked that were not favored over more meatier supports like blitzcrank,, ali, or braum, or even Nami, an enchanter who overall is still strong without it, and basically left her other class members in the dust.

The reasoning is that the enchanters kit is almost naturally toxic to the game since it doesn't provide a lot of thought input to pull off amazing stuff. Right now, Janna, Lulu, and Sona somewhat boast some of the highest winrates for quite a few first-time or newer players to the champion, over 50% winrates all around. Now, if it was after 50 games, or 100 games, it would be quite reasonable to say "Enchanters are just strong". But when the subject majority can easily rock over 50% without even needing the basic skills of the champion because one item is particularly busted, we have a problem. Enchanters overall needed a way to be appealing without being, well, anti-fun. Janna and Lulu embody anti-fun. Lulu harasses far too much, capable of being played midlane without much thought as a secondary support-mage, and can outright deny engages just by point on a target and giving them a silence. She is one of the ONLY characters with a point and click silence that is still in the game. Janna equally denies basically a ton of all-ins, forcing teams to plan their entire engages solely around if janna shows up, and dictates the fight based on her reaction. Right now, supports can decide a game, and Riot has state they despise having a single lane the center of a match naturally because of how the mechanics of a character work.

This happened in years previous where the cheese krugs/gromp level 3 botlane gank was the literal embodiment of toxicity. The same goes for Ardent Censer. The champions might need to receive a buff to compensate for the loss of item power since its one of the few things keeping them most relevant, not saying just to buff support as a whole. Read between the lines and analyze the problems the game is facing rather than saying "You're wrong because we shouldn't buff _blank_ because _blank_ (2) is still viable" Yes, whatever else is viable will still be solid, but when the item Ardent Censer was the MOST used item name in the entire week 1 group stage. Hell, Cloud 9 strategically played around the fact that Janna and Lulu were the most played supports and focused their game plans around those being one of the champions picked for theirs, and one for the opponents, and designed the rest of their comp to deal with the respective response support pick.

When a single character pick dictates the game, _something has to change_ Because no one wants to win or lose almost solely based on whether or not someone gains a good lead with a dumb item early on.

Of course, people soon realized it was kinda foolish since only a few were real threats and quite a few lategame carry types popped up, but not before the buff occur almost at the same time. The item's power spike discovery lead it to be the most unintentional buff in history, similar to the stoneplate cho'gath interaction. It was never intended to be that powerful, but it just amplified and forced required picks just to compete with the item.

Essentially, it wasn't people screaming for a buff, it was riot deciding they wanted to see an item more, because it wasn't seeing play, and so they overcompensated. Its not a diss to riot, its that both riot and players had said things and not thought of the consequences, but the players already notified "nvm you guys fixed it" but Riot never caught that memo, and so overcompensated in a lacking role by making it ridiculous

Tank Yasuo and Duskblade were only a problem in the sense that you people called them that, Malz was a problem because they wanted to make both AD and AP Malz work, Censer only became this powerful because of Coin's gold generation but those are some fair points.

You should remove Nami and Karma from the list of homogeneous enchanters, because neither play like Soraka/Sona/Janna/Lulu. They are the offensive Enchanters, and gain much more from trying to rip peoples heart out than playing passively(Karma's passive/ult rely on her doing that, and Nami's heal is only fully used if there is an enemy to bounce it off off). Not to mention both get more out of going ap with {{item:3303}} and {{item:3174}} then they do by going {{item:3301}} and {{item:3504}}.(though they still pick up ardent because it gives +heal/shield which boosts grail healing, and 60 ap, which boosts their damage and therefore their grail healing)

Also Nami's heal is modified by a multiplier of -85%, and gains 7.5% per 100 ap. That means she needs at least 200 hp to have her damage/heal unchanged by the bounces, and over that to have them actually gain power by bouncing, combine that with her passive speed boost and her e's slow scaling off of ap and pure ap serves her better than pure % hsp boosts(though a mix is, of course, more impactful than pure of either, like how ad+crit is more impactful than pure ad or pure crit, and by pure crit I mean no {{item:3508}} or {{item:3031}}, just crit+as items).

Karma, despite being an aggressive enchanter, is ultimately still very generic enchanter. One poke ability (Q), one utility skill (W root), one shield (E). Which button does which might change from champion to champion, but she's got the standard enchanter skillset. The only thing really unique to her is Mantra.

Karma gets Ardent Censer for far more than just the Grail heal boosting, considering she's one of the few supports that can apply the passive team-wide without the use of an ultimate/Stoneborn Pact/Redemption/Locket. Because of how low her shield's cooldown gets, she can even have it active on two people simultaneously. 

Also, for reference, Sona was _designed_ as an aggressive enchanter, and still necessitates AP, considering all of her utility barring the stun duration on her ultimate scales with it. She's one of the top cases to be made for {{item:3174}}, along with Karma. Karma and Sona occupy much the same space from an item perspective. The reason Sona isn't usually as aggressive anymore is because she's incredibly frail with very limited tools to protect herself, and after the last few nerfs to her damage potential, plus the death of {{item:3303}} as a viable starting item for enchanters, she's usually better off playing back until she can start scaling.

...Dude, that's the point of the warding changes.

"A support controlling warding all by themselves" was not fun, interactive or interesting. It consisted of a single support dedicating 50% or more of their income to filling their inventory with wards and clearing out any wards they saw. Supports didn't get to build items in most cases. In addition, warding wasn't strategic and it sure as hell wasn't a decision. You farted wards all over the map so that you could get the entire map looking like you turned off fog-of-war. There was nothing creative or decision-based around it. There was no "strategy" to warding beyond dumping as many wards as you can.

Also, supports have -always- been slaves to the meta items. They just change season by season. Sometime it's 10 stacks of greenwards, sometimes it's runic bulwark, sometimes it's ardent. At least now there's more experimentation. 

I'm not defending ardent because that shit is legit broken (Even though I think the goal for supports to have attractive itemization is a nice one) but please don't justify the terribly awful time of supporting in earlier seasons as "strategic warding" and "Giving supports more power/control", because the last thing a support had in S1/S2 was that.

Compared to earlyier season, we had the limit that prevents lighting up the entier map, but wardstones had more wards and you could get extra wards so you could 'move' the 3 wards around to where they are needed rather easily. Now you need to recall every time you want to move your vision around, or once they expire.
Another HUGE difference from then to now is how much allies can contribute. In S4/5, everyone could get green wards, and totems actually were quite awsome, so the rest could really contribute to vision, covering core areas like baron/dragon, which freed the support up to be more creative about their wards.
Now, the burden of vision still is prettymuch on support(and jungle) because even if they want, the rest simply can't bring any meaningfull contribution. Combined with the 'recall for every ward trip' issue, this makes it near impossible to do more than the absolute minimum as support, especially since most soloQ junglers don't go for the trackers.

I think going back to S4/5 vision and then workeing a bit from there woul be ideal, like increasing the wardlimit to 4 as passive on sightstone, maybe some refile mechanic on sightstone, and finally a wardslot that can be used for either greens or controllwards.
With some buffs to sightston and totems, one might even be able to remove greenwards and thus reduce the impact from gold on vision.
But to be honest, anything would be better than the current darkness, even S1/2...

While I agree with your point and I wouldn't mind an upgrade that lets your yellow ward regen faster (So that you can get more use out of your vision as a non-support), I do think that you're still missing the mark: Vision isn't strictly on jungle/support. It -is- on them for deep ward and by far taking the biggest risk in most cases. In addition, supports/junglers are usually the ones getting ward items, meaning they have the important job of getting anti-ward coverage down. (Unless duskblade)

I'm, however, a bit biased because I play jungler. I enjoy being able to pull off ganks easier because the enemy wastes wards and doesn't cover their backs. It feels good to clear out the small bit of vision they have and control their map because they made the mistake of warding too early, etc. I think darkness is important. It makes the times you CAN ward more important and makes you really pay more attention to map control. Plus it forces you to prioritize which areas you want to control, For example: Do you control baron or dragon late game? Do you ward all over Baron and make sure they have zero approach or do you 50/50 dragon and baron so you can't be caught off guard? etc. The macroplay is there, it's just more strategic because of how limited your resources are.

That said, I'd be fine with having a backpack/buy slot so you can always have a red-ward on-hand. I'll fully admit it does feel shitty to not be able to place a red ward because you're at six items. I think if we were to do that, having those 5 extra wards at ALL times would be incredibly helpful. But that's just my take on it and I'll admit I have my own biases about vision.

_The direction to differentiate her_: Play up the cc/keep away pattern of Janna, and downplay the ability to defend against those who wish to keep their distance(the likes of {{champion:51}} {{champion:99}} {{champion:110}} ect) or want to go in and out of combat({{champion:245}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:35}}). _What parts of her kit could be changed_: So based on what has been said on r/Janna, very few Janna's are that beholden to her sheild's ad increase. They don't necessarily want it reduced, but if it was removed entirely and replaced with something that made more sense thematically, they would be fine with that(some even want that to be the case). Another place that could be looked at would be her ult, more specifically the secondary effect of channeling it. If the healing _had_ to be reduced, adding a small slow(or rather, adding the slow back), could be one way to go. {{champion:16}} Embodiment of healing. Soraka hates the suffering of those around her, and would be willing to sacrifice herself to save another. Some of the most enjoyable times as Soraka is when you are keeping your team alive and healthy, even while you are trying to balance on the tight rope of death.

_A way to differentiate her_: Honestly, out of all the enchanters Soraka is the least like the others in playstyle. Unfortunately, while being so good at healing she is the healing goalpost for the BBI(Banana-Burn Index) She isn't exactly uncontested. While she isn't the most balanced of champs(Gw exists in part because of her), 4/5 of her abilities interact with healing in some way(passive gives her ms towards those who need healing, q heals her when she hits it, w heals and transfers her regeneration, ult heals everyone) and there isn't that much that can be done without taking some of her healing away.

_What parts of her kit could be changed_: All of her kit is dedicated to one thing, so the only way something can be done is if you remove some of her healing power and gave her some other direction in addition to healing. {{champion:37}} The Grand Maestro. A renowned musician, Sona travels far and wide performing on her Etwal, able to pluck her audience's heartstrings as easily as she does her instrument's. _A way to differentiate her_: Sona is a famous musician, and famous musicians are only powerful if they have many people listening to them, right? Sona should be a top contender for the spot of "best teamfight support", because who doesn't like a ballroom blitz? Her identity of an aura support, while sometimes ignored for her ability to obliterate some poor person, has been what drew some Sona mains to her(back when her auras were actually sustained auras). While Sona has always been somewhat a generalist support(can't compete with Nami in healing, can't do as much damage as Zyra, can't move around the map as fast or as well as Bard), she can do a little of everything. But who says she can't do that in a unique way?

_What parts of her kit could be changed_: How her aura's work. Currently each time you cast a spell an aura briefly surrounds you and it does stuff(ms buff, on-hit damage that no one seems to take advantage of and cannot affect towers, small shield) While it works, it isn't very true to the music theme. When you pluck a note, that note hangs in the air even after you pluck another. It doesn't suddenly disappear, adding nothing to the mix. What could be done is have each spell cast build up Sona's sustained aura( with her q giving more damage, her w more defenses, and her e faster movement speed) along with a stronger but shorter lasting aura(as it is on live) appearing for each cast. Sustained aura would be weaker, but would be a mix of the last 3 spells(2+ of one spell would stack the effects, like dragons do), allowing her to choose what song, and what mix of effects, she needs to play.

Another idea, if the first doesn't work out, would be for her spells to be stronger the more champions there are around her(maybe have it be the highest # in the last few seconds so that ally or enemy deaths wouldn't suddenly weaken her). This would kind-of force her to be a teamfight champ as she would only be at her strongest in a full blown 5v5, but it is an interesting idea to toy with. It would also give her the weakness of not being as strong if she is caught out alone.
